title: What is the Bedrock Basis for Truth? Who Do You Really Want to Be?.The Marriage of Science and Faith
description:
Michael and I discuss potential topics for future conversations.

Owen Barfield on the evolution of consciousness.
Levy Bruhl, French anthropologist, the consciousness of tribal peoples.
At the basis of truth is one of the things we know for sure. We are going to die and don't have all the time in the world to figure things out.
How do you conceptualize the life you've been given? Gift? or Burden?
Suffering produces a pressure to push out the parts of me that I don't like.
We all need a heaven to go towards and a hell to run from.
Decision making results from habits of thought that are laid down over years. These shape our perceptions of the world.
Alpha thinking and beta thinking.
Every action, every decision, has a moral component to it.
Turning from the bad to the good gets laid down into your hardware.
Who are you? A story, a data compression of deep patterns and associations developed over all of your decisions.
Who do you want to be?
What moved Michael from faith and then back to faith was looking at God #1 and God #2. He grew up in a faith that was narrowly focused on a small sliver of life, not a god of the whole world, but only of a separate small sliver of reality.
The manifest image and the scientific image - there is a coherence between these two.

Fear, the desire to know the truth of things in the right here and now.
It's difficult to commit to a process when you don't know how it's going to turn out.
We are all in the process of something. We have intuitions of what is good and what is not good. Some of the greatness of what we do is hidden from us.
Evangelicalism has focused on God #2 and on the mercy aspect so that some have turned to that as an excuse. Others have turned perfection into its own sort of game.
Being or becoming? Skin in the game?
